class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Flife%20sciences%2Four%20insights%2Freimagining%20the%20future%20of%20biopharma%20manufacturing%2Freimagining-the-future-of-biopharma-manufacturing.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="reimagining-the-future-of-biopharma-manufacturing" data-layer-report-name="reimagining-the-future-of-biopharma-manufacturing>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (7 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Over the past two years,</strong> the biopharmaceuticals industry has disrupted its established ways of working to deliver on humanitarian needs. New drugs have been approved in months rather than years. Manufacturing capacities have been added in a quarter of the usual time. Companies have revamped their collaborations with suppliers and contract development and manufacturing organizations (CDMOs) to accelerate drug delivery. And hybrid working models have been instituted to manage plant operations despite staffing shortages.</p>
<p>The question now is whether biopharma can sustain and potentially build on this extraordinary metamorphosis. The answer is a definitive yes, but making it happen will require a bold reimagination of the role of digital and analytics across manufacturing operations.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Digital and analytics can enable companies to bring the plant of the future to life today, yielding leaps in quality, speed, agility, and resilience. Leading biopharmaceutical players have already used these tools to achieve significant spikes in performance, including an increase of up to 40 percent in plant capacity, a 20 percent reduction in lead time, and a 15 percent reduction in conversion costs. This article will look at how biopharma manufacturing can unlock value through digital, how leaders can set the right strategic ambitions for their organizations, and which approaches are most likely to lead to success.</p>
<h2>A vision for digital in biopharma manufacturing</h2>
<p>What might manufacturing operations look like if biopharma companies adopt digital and analytics at scale? Consider the way digital technology has reshaped the auto industry, transforming the design, manufacturing, and environmental impact of cars in little more than a decade while enabling autonomous vehicles and other new driver experiences. In much the same way, digital could open up an array of innovative possibilities in biopharma manufacturing. The biopharma <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/operations-can-launch-the-next-blockbuster-in-pharma">plant of the future</a> will deliver a variety of benefits from the following features (Exhibit 1):</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/reimagining%20the%20future%20of%20biopharma%20manufacturing/svgz-elevatingambitiondigitalbiopharma-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Multiple proven use cases are already making the vision of the biopharma plant of the future realistic and achievable." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/reimagining%20the%20future%20of%20biopharma%20manufacturing/svgz-elevatingambitiondigitalbiopharma-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<ul>
    <li><em>No-touch planning.</em> The adoption of digital twinsreal-time, virtual versions of physical objects and processescan enable biopharma companies to optimally balance short- and long-term demand with supply of raw materials, equipment capacity, and human assets (staffing), and allow companies to overhaul the scheduling of production and lab activities.</li>
    <li><em>Reimagined processes.</em> Automation and advanced production technologies such as line sensing, augmented- and assisted-reality tools, and parametric product releases can enable human operators to make remarkable gains in productivity.</li>
    <li><em>Zero deviations.</em> Advanced analytics models can help plant leaders predict and mitigate quality risks, ensure compliance, and maximize product robustness.</li>
    <li><em>Paper-free factory operations.</em> Electronic documentation can create a seamless information flow from raw-material supply to planning to production to quality to warehouse, spanning internal and third-party manufacturing networks.</li>
    <li><em>Proactive risk management.</em> Predictive analytics can enable real-time monitoring and management of maintenance, environmental, quality, and other supply-chain risks to maximize throughput, cost, compliance, and sustainability.</li>
    <li><em>Remote performance monitoring.</em> Interconnected systems can allow real-time tracking of site performance, product status, and issue detection, resulting in more effective decision making by management.</li>
</ul>
<p>Together, these changes could usher in a new era for biopharma manufacturing. Asset utilization and labor productivity could be doubled, product transfer times could be cut from months to days, the costs of poor quality could be all but eliminated, and conversion costs could be reduced by as much as 80 percenton top of all the other advantages of more agile, more resilient operations. Far-fetched as it may sound, this vision is within reach, as demonstrated by McKinseys research on industry 4.0, conducted in collaboration with the World Economic Forum, and its experience of supporting companies digital transformations. It is clear that digital manufacturing can help companies develop new business models, expand capacity, boost productivity, and build lasting business value.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0396391c-9c2e-4278-8ffb-5c6f95b2408b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0396391c-9c2e-4278-8ffb-5c6f95b2408b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See Enno de Boer, Helena Leurent, and Adrian Widmer, <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/lighthouse-manufacturers-lead-the-way">Lighthouse manufacturers lead the waycan the rest of the world keep up?</a>, McKinsey, January 7, 2019; and Francisco Betti, Enno de Boer, and Yves Giraud, <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/industrys-fast-mover-advantage-enterprise-value-from-digital-factories">Industrys fast-mover advantage: Enterprise value from digital factories</a>, McKinsey, January 10, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Leading biopharma companies have already begun to capture some of these benefits, although not yet at full scale. An array of digital and advanced-analytics use cases have brought radical improvements in the most critical performance metrics: a 30 to 50 percent reduction in deviations (with an 80 percent reduction in recurring deviations), a 25 to 40 percent increase in plant capacity, a 15 to 20 percent reduction in lead times, and a 30 to 50 percent increase in direct and indirect plant operation productivity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cc0c0679-5f48-4b8e-910e-a203252672ee"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span collaboration with the World Economic Forum.
    </span></span></span></a></span> Perhaps most important, a digitally enabled workplace led by digital natives will not only make these dramatic improvements in performance but also sustain their impact over time (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/reimagining%20the%20future%20of%20biopharma%20manufacturing/svgz-elevatingambitiondigitalbiopharma-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Multiple proven use cases are already making the vision of the biopharma plant of the future realistic and achievable." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/reimagining%20the%20future%20of%20biopharma%20manufacturing/svgz-elevatingambitiondigitalbiopharma-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Setting ambitions for digital</h2>
<p>To capture full value from digital manufacturing, companies need to set the right ambitionsones that are bold and in line with their broader strategic aspirations. This can help unite the organization behind a common purpose and ensure that resources are directed to the areas that need them most. When setting their ambitions, companies should consider six elements:</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>To capture full value from digital manufacturing, companies need to set the right ambitionsones that are bold and in line with their broader strategic aspirations.</p></blockquote></div>
<ul>
    <li><em>Impact.</em> What level of improvement do we expect our digital transformation to deliver? Are we working to change any one aspect of our performance or to optimize the full range of metrics across quality, throughput, productivity, cost, timelines, and talent?</li>
    <li><em>Scale.</em> How far will our transformation extend? Should we focus on a specific area, such as a quality lab; address all manufacturing operations across an entire site; or the entire manufacturing network?</li>
    <li><em>Leadership and governance.</em> How should we manage our transformation? Should we take a top-down approach led by central resources with local site teams overseeing implementation? Or should we opt for a bottom-up approach led by site teams with support from a digital center of excellence?</li>
    <li><em>Technology and data.</em> What investments must we make in IT (for example, manufacturing execution systems, laboratory information management systems), operational technology (for example, production-line sensors), and data infrastructure, including data processing and storage? Should we rely on readily available data sources and minimize changes to our existing infrastructure, or would it be better to build a future-proof tech infrastructure that allows us to derive novel insights from new sources of data?</li>
    <li><em>Production systems.</em> How far should we digitize our production and management systems? Should we adopt specific digital and analytical solutions to improve current processes or redesign our entire production system to make the most of digital tools, technological advances, and new ways of working?</li>
    <li><em>Workforce capability and culture. </em>Should we use change agents and experts to build digital capabilities in specific areas? Or should we instead reorient our whole organizational culture around digital working, committing to a major upskilling and reskilling effort?</li>
</ul>
<p>Thoughtful choices in these six dimensions will help an organization consider how it can achieve its digital aspirations, what resources it will need, and what return it can expect on its investment. Any of these choicesor a combination of themcould be optimal under the right circumstances. Many solutions can help companies deliver on their desired outcomes; however, these decisions will profoundly affect the approach to the digital transformation.</p>
<h2>Charting the digital journey </h2>
<p>Although organizations may have different ambitions, companies that succeed in making digital headway typically follow one of three paths: implementing use cases, developing lighthouse sites, and transforming the entire network.</p>
<h3>Implementing use cases</h3>
<p>The path of implementing use cases targets a series of digital projects rather than implementing a broader suite of digital offerings across a value chain. Companies typically address specific pain points that recur at multiple sites in a network, such as high deviation rates, low yields, subpar lab productivity, or slow batch changeovers.</p>
<p>One global biopharma manufacturer implemented digital use cases to improve yield in fermentation and primary recovery processes in a specific manufacturing line. The company built an in silico model that optimized batch, asset, and human parameters in real time while requiring minimal disturbance to existing production systems and governance models. The effort was led by a cross-functional site team with advanced-analytics capabilities developed through a tailor-made learning program. Not only did the company improve its yield in the targeted processes by 5 to 10 percent, it also built a backbone of data pipelines and machine-learning models it could scale up to other cell lines and sites across its network. In addition, it built targeted capabilities across the organization that caused similar initiatives to mushroom from the bottom up.</p>
<h3>Developing lighthouse sites</h3>
<p>Companies that develop lighthouse sites implement a holistic digital transformation across end-to-end operations at a few sites. This maximizes each sites potential in line with its business priorities while enabling the company to settle on an approach to the transformation that can be codified and rolled out to other sites across the network.</p>
<p>A global biopharma manufacturer sought to increase throughput at one of its plants while tackling planning, production, and quality challenges arising from workforce attrition and a complex product portfolio. The company decided to develop the site as a beacon illuminating a new way of managing manufacturing operations. Leaders invested in technology upgrades rallied the plant team around a vision of future growth and set up a capability-building academy to turn the vision into reality. They implemented ten use cases along the sites value chain and built a pipeline of several others to be implemented over the next 12 to 18 months. In less than a year, the company increased plant throughput by 40 percent and the capacity of its quality lab by 50 percent. Deviations were reduced by 80 percent, repeat deviations were eliminated, and manufacturing conversion costs fell by 20 percent. The site was recognized by the WEF as one of the first digital lighthouses in biopharma globally, and the company is now scaling up its effort to other locations in its network. Several other pharma playersinnovators, generics, CDMOs, and morehave had success with a similar approach.</p>
<h3>Transforming the entire network</h3>
<p>The objective of transforming the entire network is to reengineer site operations throughout the manufacturing network and across all technology platforms and locations. The approach relies on a bold vision to create a culture that embraces digital as central to all ways of working, supported by a capability-building effort that spans every level of the organization (see sidebar, Stages of a typical digital manufacturing transformation). Compared with the other approaches, successful network transformation requires significantly more management focus, investments, and other resources, and the impact on the overall companys performance also is much greater.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Stages of a typical digital manufacturing transformation</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>From our research,</strong> experience, and conversations with industry experts, we have identified three broad questions that companies looking at large-scale manufacturing transformation should consider. Answering each of these questions includes several activities that can help the company get closer to a successful transformation.</p>
<h3>Where are we today, and how good can we be?</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Inspire key stakeholders through digital orientation boot camps and go-and-see sessions.</li>
    <li>Estimate the value at stake and identify all priority use cases.</li>
    <li>Assess foundational elementsdigital capabilities, culture, and information technology (IT), and operational technology (OT) infrastructureand establish why previous digital efforts may not have scaled.</li>
    <li>Develop a high-level business case and digital ambition for selected sites.</li>
</ul>
<h3>How do we build momentum for the digital journey?</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Agree on the business case and ambition with key site and corporate leaders.</li>
    <li>Build and align on a digital road map, including the selection and sequencing of use cases.</li>
    <li>Set up a central team or center of excellence and program governance to oversee the digital journey.</li>
    <li>Identify core team members at selected sites for the first wave of design and implementation.</li>
    <li>Design a communications campaign to kick-start the digital journey.</li>
</ul>
<h3>How do we make it happen?</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Build capabilities through cohort-based learning journeys.
    </li>
    <li>Design and implement priority use cases and IT/OT changes through agile sprints executed in multiple implementation waves.
    </li>
    <li>Design and launch culture change initiatives.
    </li>
    <li>Develop a plan for subsequent sprints to ensure continuous digital innovation.
    </li>
    <li>Codify the approach and tools for scale-up across the network.
    </li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Although a few biopharma companies have recently embarked on a network-wide digital transformation, examples from other industries show that this approach can be achieved. For instance, one global electronics company set itself the ambitious goal of using digital to achieve autonomous operations across a network of more than 30 production sites. The chairman and executive team began by developing an inspirational change story and cascading it across the organization, going on to deliver a package of more than 4,000 initiatives across the first set of sites in three years. The effort was governed by a new digital center of excellence and supported by a digital academy that trained more than 1,000 initiative owners globally. Through a combination of digital and AI use cases, the company automated up to 70 percent of its manually intensive activities in key processes, with impressive results: down time, lead times, and quality losses were halved, while labor productivity doubled.</p>
<h2>Getting started</h2>
<p>Success stories like the previous example of digital transformation should convince biopharma organizations they can unlock value from digital manufacturing by setting a bold digital ambition and deploying any of these approaches. As the initial efforts start to bear fruit and the impact from digital expands, the company may progress from one approach to another. For example, it could begin with use cases and move to a broader transformation over time. In our experience, however, the best way to achieve critical velocity for change in biopharma manufacturing is to start with a lighthouse approach that improves performance holistically across a plant, using the experience to create a recipe to scale up across the network.</p>
<p>Leaders should begin their manufacturing transformation by taking stock of their digital maturity. This involves conducting a comprehensive assessment of the organizations operational performance, ongoing digital pilots, technology infrastructure, and capabilities. Before developing the business case in their own context, they should draw inspiration and gain insights from digital leaders across industries. Lessons from other industries can inform the digital ambition around which they will align and mobilize the organization, draw up an execution road map, and forge capabilities to drive the transformation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9c844110-cfa5-4970-9f66-3ae4f387f306"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9c844110-cfa5-4970-9f66-3ae4f387f306" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For a perspective on how to maximize the benefits of digital and analytics in biopharma operations, see Stephanie Bayer, Sulay Sandy, Ulf Schrader, and Matthias Spiegl, <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/leveraging-digital-and-analytics-in-biopharma-operations-six-principles">Leveraging digital and analytics in biopharma operations: Six principles</a>, McKinsey, May 27, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<hr>
<p>To keep pace with innovation, overcome the headwinds buffeting the industry, and meet customer needs in a timely way, biopharma manufacturing must become more agile, efficient, and value-consciousa need best met by embracing digital in manufacturing. The prize for companies that succeed will be greater resilience to future shocks and new ways of working that should serve them well for decades to come.</p></div><div id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Reimagining the future of biopharma manufacturing","displayName":"Reimagining the future of biopharma manufacturing","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"db191882-8e64-4ad2-bac0-fe7be04790aa","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Reimagining the future of biopharma manufacturing"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Future of biopharma manufacturing"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Leveraging digital and analytics advances can unlock significant value for biopharma companies through gains in quality, speed, agility, and resilience."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-10-11T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOver the past two years,\u003c/strong\u003e the biopharmaceuticals industry has disrupted its established ways of working to deliver on humanitarian needs. New drugs have been approved in months rather than years. Manufacturing capacities have been added in a quarter of the usual time. Companies have revamped their collaborations with suppliers and contract development and manufacturing organizations (CDMOs) to accelerate drug delivery. And hybrid working models have been instituted to manage plant operations despite staffing shortages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe question now is whether biopharma can sustain and potentially build on this extraordinary metamorphosis. The answer is a definitive yes, but making it happen will require a bold reimagination of the role of digital and analytics across manufacturing operations.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eDigital and analytics can enable companies to bring the plant of the future to life today, yielding leaps in quality, speed, agility, and resilience. Leading biopharmaceutical players have already used these tools to achieve significant spikes in performance, including an increase of up to 40 percent in plant capacity, a 20 percent reduction in lead time, and a 15 percent reduction in conversion costs. This article will look at how biopharma manufacturing can unlock value through digital, how leaders can set the right strategic ambitions for their organizations, and which approaches are most likely to lead to success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eA vision for digital in biopharma manufacturing\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat might manufacturing operations look like if biopharma companies adopt digital and analytics at scale? Consider the way digital technology has reshaped the auto industry, transforming the design, manufacturing, and environmental impact of cars in little more than a decade while enabling autonomous vehicles and other new driver experiences. In much the same way, digital could open up an array of innovative possibilities in biopharma manufacturing. The biopharma \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/operations-can-launch-the-next-blockbuster-in-pharma\"\u003eplant of the future\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will deliver a variety of benefits from the following features (Exhibit 1):\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eNo-touch planning.\u003c/em\u003e The adoption of digital twins\u0026mdash;real-time, virtual versions of physical objects and processes\u0026mdash;can enable biopharma companies to optimally balance short- and long-term demand with supply of raw materials, equipment capacity, and human assets (staffing), and allow companies to overhaul the scheduling of production and lab activities.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReimagined processes.\u003c/em\u003e Automation and advanced production technologies such as line sensing, augmented- and assisted-reality tools, and parametric product releases can enable human operators to make remarkable gains in productivity.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eZero deviations.\u003c/em\u003e Advanced analytics models can help plant leaders predict and mitigate quality risks, ensure compliance, and maximize product robustness.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePaper-free factory operations.\u003c/em\u003e Electronic documentation can create a seamless information flow from raw-material supply to planning to production to quality to warehouse, spanning internal and third-party manufacturing networks.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProactive risk management.\u003c/em\u003e Predictive analytics can enable real-time monitoring and management of maintenance, environmental, quality, and other supply-chain risks to maximize throughput, cost, compliance, and sustainability.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRemote performance monitoring.\u003c/em\u003e Interconnected systems can allow real-time tracking of site performance, product status, and issue detection, resulting in more effective decision making by management.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTogether, these changes could usher in a new era for biopharma manufacturing. Asset utilization and labor productivity could be doubled, product transfer times could be cut from months to days, the costs of poor quality could be all but eliminated, and conversion costs could be reduced by as much as 80 percent\u0026mdash;on top of all the other advantages of more agile, more resilient operations. Far-fetched as it may sound, this vision is within reach, as demonstrated by McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s research on industry 4.0, conducted in collaboration with the World Economic Forum, and its experience of supporting companies\u0026rsquo; digital transformations. It is clear that digital manufacturing can help companies develop new business models, expand capacity, boost productivity, and build lasting business value.[[Footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLeading biopharma companies have already begun to capture some of these benefits, although not yet at full scale. An array of digital and advanced-analytics use cases have brought radical improvements in the most critical performance metrics: a 30 to 50 percent reduction in deviations (with an 80 percent reduction in recurring deviations), a 25 to 40 percent increase in plant capacity, a 15 to 20 percent reduction in lead times, and a 30 to 50 percent increase in direct and indirect plant operation productivity.[[Footnote 2]]In addition, the greater transparency inherent in digital can make decision making more nimble and effective, freeing up as much as 12 to 15 percent of plant leaders\u0026rsquo; capacity.[[Footnote 3]] Perhaps most important, a digitally enabled workplace led by digital natives will not only make these dramatic improvements in performance but also sustain their impact over time (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch2\u003eSetting ambitions for digital\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo capture full value from digital manufacturing, companies need to set the right ambitions\u0026mdash;ones that are bold and in line with their broader strategic aspirations. This can help unite the organization behind a common purpose and ensure that resources are directed to the areas that need them most. When setting their ambitions, companies should consider six elements:\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Pullquote 1]]\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eImpact.\u003c/em\u003e What level of improvement do we expect our digital transformation to deliver? Are we working to change any one aspect of our performance or to optimize the full range of metrics across quality, throughput, productivity, cost, timelines, and talent?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eScale.\u003c/em\u003e How far will our transformation extend? Should we focus on a specific area, such as a quality lab; address all manufacturing operations across an entire site; or the entire manufacturing network?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLeadership and governance.\u003c/em\u003e How should we manage our transformation? Should we take a top-down approach led by central resources with local site teams overseeing implementation? Or should we opt for a bottom-up approach led by site teams with support from a digital center of excellence?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTechnology and data.\u003c/em\u003e What investments must we make in IT (for example, manufacturing execution systems, laboratory information management systems), operational technology (for example, production-line sensors), and data infrastructure, including data processing and storage? Should we rely on readily available data sources and minimize changes to our existing infrastructure, or would it be better to build a future-proof tech infrastructure that allows us to derive novel insights from new sources of data?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProduction systems.\u003c/em\u003e How far should we digitize our production and management systems? Should we adopt specific digital and analytical solutions to improve current processes or redesign our entire production system to make the most of digital tools, technological advances, and new ways of working?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWorkforce capability and culture. \u003c/em\u003eShould we use change agents and experts to build digital capabilities in specific areas? Or should we instead reorient our whole organizational culture around digital working, committing to a major upskilling and reskilling effort?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThoughtful choices in these six dimensions will help an organization consider how it can achieve its digital aspirations, what resources it will need, and what return it can expect on its investment. Any of these choices\u0026mdash;or a combination of them\u0026mdash;could be optimal under the right circumstances. Many solutions can help companies deliver on their desired outcomes; however, these decisions will profoundly affect the approach to the digital transformation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCharting the digital journey \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough organizations may have different ambitions, companies that succeed in making digital headway typically follow one of three paths: implementing use cases, developing \u0026ldquo;lighthouse\u0026rdquo; sites, and transforming the entire network.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eImplementing use cases\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe path of implementing use cases targets a series of digital projects rather than implementing a broader suite of digital offerings across a value chain. Companies typically address specific pain points that recur at multiple sites in a network, such as high deviation rates, low yields, subpar lab productivity, or slow batch changeovers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne global biopharma manufacturer implemented digital use cases to improve yield in fermentation and primary recovery processes in a specific manufacturing line. The company built an in silico model that optimized batch, asset, and human parameters in real time while requiring minimal disturbance to existing production systems and governance models. The effort was led by a cross-functional site team with advanced-analytics capabilities developed through a tailor-made learning program. Not only did the company improve its yield in the targeted processes by 5 to 10 percent, it also built a backbone of data pipelines and machine-learning models it could scale up to other cell lines and sites across its network. In addition, it built targeted capabilities across the organization that caused similar initiatives to mushroom from the bottom up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDeveloping lighthouse sites\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies that develop lighthouse sites implement a holistic digital transformation across end-to-end operations at a few sites. This maximizes each site\u0026rsquo;s potential in line with its business priorities while enabling the company to settle on an approach to the transformation that can be codified and rolled out to other sites across the network.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA global biopharma manufacturer sought to increase throughput at one of its plants while tackling planning, production, and quality challenges arising from workforce attrition and a complex product portfolio. The company decided to develop the site as a beacon illuminating a new way of managing manufacturing operations. Leaders invested in technology upgrades rallied the plant team around a vision of future growth and set up a capability-building academy to turn the vision into reality. They implemented ten use cases along the site\u0026rsquo;s value chain and built a pipeline of several others to be implemented over the next 12 to 18 months. In less than a year, the company increased plant throughput by 40 percent and the capacity of its quality lab by 50 percent. Deviations were reduced by 80 percent, repeat deviations were eliminated, and manufacturing conversion costs fell by 20 percent. The site was recognized by the WEF as one of the first digital lighthouses in biopharma globally, and the company is now scaling up its effort to other locations in its network. Several other pharma players\u0026mdash;innovators, generics, CDMOs, and more\u0026mdash;have had success with a similar approach.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTransforming the entire network\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe objective of transforming the entire network is to reengineer site operations throughout the manufacturing network and across all technology platforms and locations. The approach relies on a bold vision to create a culture that embraces digital as central to all ways of working, supported by a capability-building effort that spans every level of the organization (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Stages of a typical digital manufacturing transformation\u0026rdquo;). Compared with the other approaches, successful network transformation requires significantly more management focus, investments, and other resources, and the impact on the overall company\u0026rsquo;s performance also is much greater.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough a few biopharma companies have recently embarked on a network-wide digital transformation, examples from other industries show that this approach can be achieved. For instance, one global electronics company set itself the ambitious goal of using digital to achieve autonomous operations across a network of more than 30 production sites. The chairman and executive team began by developing an inspirational change story and cascading it across the organization, going on to deliver a package of more than 4,000 initiatives across the first set of sites in three years. The effort was governed by a new digital center of excellence and supported by a digital academy that trained more than 1,000 initiative owners globally. Through a combination of digital and AI use cases, the company automated up to 70 percent of its manually intensive activities in key processes, with impressive results: down time, lead times, and quality losses were halved, while labor productivity doubled.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eGetting started\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuccess stories like the previous example of digital transformation should convince biopharma organizations they can unlock value from digital manufacturing by setting a bold digital ambition and deploying any of these approaches. As the initial efforts start to bear fruit and the impact from digital expands, the company may progress from one approach to another. For example, it could begin with use cases and move to a broader transformation over time. In our experience, however, the best way to achieve critical velocity for change in biopharma manufacturing is to start with a lighthouse approach that improves performance holistically across a plant, using the experience to create a recipe to scale up across the network.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLeaders should begin their manufacturing transformation by taking stock of their digital maturity. This involves conducting a comprehensive assessment of the organization\u0026rsquo;s operational performance, ongoing digital pilots, technology infrastructure, and capabilities. Before developing the business case in their own context, they should draw inspiration and gain insights from digital leaders across industries. Lessons from other industries can inform the digital ambition around which they will align and mobilize the organization, draw up an execution road map, and forge capabilities to drive the transformation.[[Footnote 4]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo keep pace with innovation, overcome the headwinds buffeting the industry, and meet customer needs in a timely way, biopharma manufacturing must become more agile, efficient, and value-conscious\u0026mdash;a need best met by embracing digital in manufacturing. The prize for companies that succeed will be greater resilience to future shocks and new ways of working that should serve them well for decades to ambition with key site and corporate leaders.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBuild and align on a digital road map, including the selection and sequencing of use cases.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSet up a central team or center of excellence and program governance to oversee the digital journey.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIdentify core team members at selected sites for the first wave of design and implementation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDesign a communications campaign to kick-start the digital journey.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow do \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDevelop a plan for subsequent sprints to ensure continuous digital innovation.\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCodify the approach and tools for scale-up
